723426f.title: Manhattan: State Street - Bowling Green Row
723426f.text:
State Street, east side, south from Bowling Green Row to Pearl Street, showing a row of fashionable homes facing on Battery Park (right). Shown in the foreground, is No. 7 Bowling 9reen, at the S.E. corner of State Street. The farthest building shown, is Stewart's Store, (predecessor to John Wanamaker in the Department Store line), which occupied the block between Bridge and Pearl Streets. Stephen Whitney resided in one of the houses facing Bowling Green. Today (1937), the U.S. Custom House rises here on the area shown in the foreground, with the 12-story Battery Park Building
(former Stewart site) at its rear.
About 1860.
Ewing Galloway.
A4ae
ww~
723426f.folder: State Street & Bowling Green Row, Manhattan, NY

716806f-b.text:
-- Bowling Grgen, a northward view up Broadway from "Steemship Row", showing a view of Eew York's first park. Note the iron railing around same and the lanterns thereupon.
In the center is a pool and fountain.
Early views (circcl850 and 61) show this latter feature and which in subseduent views (1684) is absent, tho the pool :6hained. The last date given is that of Produce Exchange Building construction, replacing the buildings on the right. To the left on Broadway, appear ovate shaped sewer pipes and a partial excavation for same. These Were introduced in 1860 anu were 4x2.8 feet in diameter. In 18o4 vitrified pipe was first laid. Across the foreground are suspended electric wires and at the extreme right is an old street illuminating
gas lamp.
For dedication ceremony (April 6, 1938) see New York City newspapers for February anu March. Views similar to this are in these files and in a volume of newspaper clippings titled "New York City Views" American History Dvision - Room 300 New York Public Library,several of whicn are credited to
the Consoliuated Edison Company.
Between 1861 and 1864
Rockwood Photo
E--Broa way north from Bowling Green
Thaddeus Wilderson  about 1900
522 W. 145th.Street
New York City

716814f-a.text:
Bowling Green: 'ew York's first park photographed southward down Broadway. This thoroughfare is on the right and Battery Park is just beyond. Buildings appearing through the trees are units of the former residences that now form "Steamship Row." Above
same, in the Upper Bay, lies Governor's Island.
About 1875
Roege, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

716809f-a.text:
Bowling Green Park: New Yorks first park, located at the foot of Broadway. The buildings in the background are upon the west side of that thoroughfare, extending between Battery Place (left) and Morris Street (right). The Columbia Building stands at the N. W. corner of the 1atter point. To the north is the Aldrich Court.
About 1885
Gift of the Urbrock Collection

716956f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from Bowling Green and showing prominently the Seaboard National Bank (No. 18) and the Standard Oil Building (No. 26). Subsequently,this latter corporation purchased the Bank site and erected upon same. Eings Hand book of New York, 1892, carries an account of this financial institution and a similar illustration on page 692.
1889.
Brown Brothers.

716938f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing tho foot of this important Manhattan thoroughfare. The City's first park, the Green, is in the center behind the street car. The buildings there are on the east side and were later replaced with the outstanding Standard Gil Building. At the left margin is No. 1 Broadway.
About 1900

716945f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green. The intersection shown on the right, is B)aver Strcet, with the 7-story Produce Building at the S.E. corner. The towered Standard Oil Co. Building (Nos. 8 to 26 Broadway) ocoupies the N.E. corner. Prominent buildings shown on the left, (west side of Broadway), and in the order of their appearance are the: Washington, Bowling Green, Cdnard, Columbia, Adams, American Railway Eypress Co., Empire, Trinity
and Singer.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.

716946f-a.text:
Broadway, north from both Battery Place and Beaver Street. (At the left is Battery P1ace and at the right is Beaver Street. This view shows Bowling Green in the centre foreground, which was originally used by the Dutch, for bowling and a drinking place, a refuge from
their respective domestic havens.
About 1925.

716973f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing the start of this thoroughfare that traverses the entire island.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.

716968f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, with Battery Place on the left, and Beaver Street on the right. Sandwiched between these building g1ants, is Bowling Green, the first public park in Manhattan, surrounding which stood the homes of Lord Cornwallis, Bord Howe, Sir Henry Clinton, George Washington, General Gates, Benedict Arnold, Talleyrand and other famous personages of American History. To-day (1937), we find encompassing same, the Washington, Bowling Green, and Cunard Buildings on the west side of Broadway, and facing the curved Standard Oil Co. Building. On the right, a portion of the U.S. Custom House obstructs a view of the Produce Exchange Building. The spired edifices in the background, are the Singer and Woolworth Buildings.
February 4, 1927.
New York Edison Company.

716819f-a.text:
Bovling Green and the U.S. Custom Bouse, as viewed southward along Broadway. Shown on the right, the west side of Broadway, and in the order of their appearance are, the Cunard Building, the Bowling Green Building, the Washington Building and Battery Park. The curved building on the opposite side, is Nos. 8-26 Broadway, the
Standard Oil Company Building.
February 21, 1928
N. Y. Edison Company.

716965f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing W.P.A. employees engaged in a street car track removal project. Note the Republican campaign banner suspended aoross Broadway, soliciting the financial and clerical workers of this district to vote for their presidential candidate, who as it eventually evolved, failed to be elected; Franklin D. Roosevelt gaining
a second term.
August 25, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

716823f-b.text:
Bowling Green viewed northward from Battery Place (in Views 1-2-3) showing the point where Broadway begins its existance.
Note the old horse car in view 1.
Visws 2-3-4 were taken to show the completion of the track reroval by the W.P.A. This agency also rehabilitated tne park
and its fanous railing.
George L. Balgue  View 1: Nov. 1905
W. P. A. Photo  View 2-3-4: February 7, 1937
Five Borouths Project

716941f.text:
(1)
Nos. 1, 5-11 and 13 to 27 Broadway, west side, north from Battery Place (left) to Morris Street (right) as seen across Bowling Oreen. Twe 12-story structure on the left (No. 1) is the Washington Building. Adjacent to same is the 17-story Bowling Green Building, No. 5-11. At the S.W. corner of Morris Street is the 5-story Stevens House, No. 21-27. Across the roof of the latter appears the south side of the 12-story Columbia Building, No. 29 Broadway, at the N.W. corner
of Morris Street.
September 25, 1906.
Brown Brothers.

(1)
Bowling Green South, east from and including State Street, to and including Broadway. Also shown is State Street, east side, south from Bowling Green South, to but not including Bridge Street. Bowling Green South was known as Steamship Row, and is now the
present site for the Custom House.
About 1885.

Broadway), the eastern boundary of the Green.
October 13, 1930.
